In our recent class discussion, we delved into the assigned reading for the week, specifically Edward S. Casey's seminal work, "Getting Back into Place  Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World." The first chapter, "Implacement," and the subsequent "Displacement," offer a thought-provoking exploration of the concept of time as the dominant force shaping our contemporary world and culture. Casey skillfully argues that our society's emphasis on time as the situating force has led to a disconnection from the notion of place as the central axis of our cultural identity. He posits that by reconceptualizing place as the foundation of culture, we can cultivate a more grounded and community-driven existence. This reading has been the most compelling thus far in our course, and I must admit that it has left a lasting impression on me.

I must admit that I was intrigued by the concept of flag-burning as a potential means of escape for those who were wrongly accused of witchcraft. As a non-American blogger, I have been hesitant to engage in discussions on this topic, particularly those surrounding the burning of flags, but since I initiated this conversation, I feel compelled to share my thoughts. In my opinion, the notion of enshrining a law against flag-burning is utterly misguided. The moment you establish a symbol, any symbol, as having automatic reverence and protection, you take a small but significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are ephemeral and their meaning is determined by how they are perceived or created to represent. It is crucial to recognize that symbols do not inherently possess inherent meaning; it is what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that holds significance.

The 2013 installment of the Shadow Warrior series, Shadow Warrior 2, boasts a plethora of impressive boss battles, with weapons that are both visually appealing and functional. While they may not quite measure up to the standards set by the highly-regarded Dark Souls series, they are still a solid offering. The enemy AI is well-balanced, and once you become accustomed to the upgrade system, it becomes relatively unobtrusive. The limited ammo and elemental abilities force you to diversify your weapon choices, which is a refreshing change from the often-repetitive gameplay found in other games of this genre. The unique and varied arsenal of weapons ensures that many remain viable throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is also noteworthy, with the main theme and additional tracks by Stan Bush being particular highlights.

I was thoroughly impressed with the Assassin's Creed series, which excelled in its execution on multiple fronts, including ship battles, sailing, hunting, and parkour, among others. As I delved deeper into the story, I found myself becoming increasingly attached to the protagonist, whose character development was well-crafted. The narrative begins with a rocky start, but it gradually improves as the game progresses, much like every action-adventure game I've played. Edward, as a character, was particularly intriguing, and so were the supporting characters. I felt that each collectible item had a tangible purpose in the game, which is something I never experienced in previous games. Perhaps this is because I sensed that they played a more significant role in the story, even if they weren't essential to the main plot. They were enjoyable to collect and were rewarded in a well-balanced manner.

While I cannot wholeheartedly endorse this game, it was not entirely unremarkable. The gunplay was satisfactory, as long as you can afford to purchase gun parts, which was my primary gripe with this game  it's a pay-to-win model. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit was fun to use and the hrv concept was an excellent idea. I would choose this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format was off-putting for me. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, I would advise against it; it's not my cup of tea.

While I've experienced some minor frustrations, I've thoroughly enjoyed this game. The save system, unfortunately, is imperfect, as the risk of sudden death can be disheartening. On my first playthrough, I suffered a setback when my main character perished around the 10-hour mark, which is roughly 10% through the game. I've since acquired a third-party mod with a save feature to prevent such catastrophic failures from occurring. Additionally, the aiming reticle is slightly undersized, and the zoom functionality could be more robust. Notwithstanding these minor drawbacks, I've found the game to be an absolute blast. As someone who doesn't typically enjoy zombie-themed games, I've been pleasantly surprised by the engaging combination of strategic gameplay, mission objectives, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up mechanics. I've found myself playing it as frequently as possible, often finding myself thinking, 'Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or I'll be running away and want to get to a safe location before shutting the game down.'

While I'm not entirely sure how many units there are, it's safe to say there are a substantial amount. The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the overall gameplay is nothing short of epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is also an added bonus, and I'm not being facetious when I say it's quite entertaining. However, if you're new to the strategy genre or underestimate the complexity of this game, it may take some time to get accustomed to it. Don't be discouraged if you lose units – it's all part of the learning process. Just make sure to plan ahead, always maintain a strong defense, and adapt to the situation at hand.

I was initially skeptical about this game before I played it, unsure if I wanted to purchase it. The concept of portal guns and portals seemed unusual to me, even though I appreciate science fiction. I was pleasantly surprised, as I discovered that the humor and voice acting in this game are truly phenomenal. The story's not cheesy (although it can be cheesy at times). The distinct personalities of the various characters are well-developed and relatable, with each one having their own unique sense of humor. The level design is also impressive, with a unique blend of complexity and accessibility. I must admit that I never played the first Portal game, but after experiencing the sequel, I'm considering taking the time to play it. In fact, I wouldn't have played it if I hadn't enjoyed the first game so much.

Embark on a nostalgic journey with this retro-style Transformers game, reminiscent of the beloved 5-minute cartoon series that captivated the hearts of 30-somethings in the UK. The iconic voice actors behind Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and other beloved characters return, instantly recognizable and nostalgic. The distinctive sound design, reminiscent of the classic cartoon, is a masterclass in evoking a bygone era. Visually, the cell-shaded graphics are a triumph, transporting players to a bygone generation. But beyond its aesthetic appeal, the game's combat mechanics are a true standout. The seamless integration of mid-fight transformations, woven into fluid combos, elevates the gameplay experience, setting it apart from other Transformers titles. Notably, the emphasis on melee combat is a refreshing change of pace, while certain enemies, such as the Seekers, require a strategic shift to ranged attacks, adding depth to the overall experience.

I recently downloaded and played the game for a short while, only to find it lacked any remarkable features. The login process was more tedious than the actual gameplay. I encountered a peculiar issue where the game prompted me to accept an update to the terms of service, only to have it repeatedly appear upon clicking 'accept'. The only solution was to restart the client, which was not a major inconvenience. I was perplexed by the requirement to link my Steam and Gface accounts, as I was told it was necessary for downloadable content. However, it's concerning that this information is not reversible, allowing an unknown company to access my Steam data. Moreover, the game itself was underwhelming, with gameplay that was easily recognizable as a clone of a popular title, except for the poor gunplay, which was somehow made worse. It's difficult to comprehend how such a fundamental aspect of the game could be compromised.

Experience the thrill of 4K resolution at 60 frames per second, courtesy of the GTX 970 graphics card, and indulge in dual audio options that cater to your unique preferences. The inclusion of Neptune Gear adds an extra layer of excitement to this exceptional port. As a newcomer to the series, this game serves as an excellent entry point, offering a rich narrative and engaging gameplay. While there is some exposition that can be skipped, the game's pacing is well-balanced, and the rebindable controls for keyboard and mouse ensure a seamless gaming experience. The price is reasonable, and the inclusion of over half the DLC at no additional cost provides ample content to keep you entertained. I highly recommend this game to fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, provided you're willing to tolerate occasional breaks in the action. For those seeking a commentary-free experience, I've curated a playlist available here  https //www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1. Cheers!

I'm thrilled to report that I experienced no performance issues, even at the initial release, and after the numerous patches, the game plays remarkably well. In my opinion, this game is an absolute delight, offering an incredibly engaging and enjoyable experience. Although, I do acknowledge that the format may be somewhat unconventional (specifically, the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress through the story), I found the 'dual play' segments, where I could play Batman alongside another player, to be a particularly standout feature. The ability to utilize the controller for most segments of the game, while using the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was a greatly appreciated touch. Moreover, driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing after the ApC commanders, is an exhilarating experience that becomes increasingly enjoyable once you master the art of using the brakes to skid around corners, and when you've mastered that, navigating the city becomes an absolute blast.

As a non-native English speaker, I'd like to provide an honest review of this exceptional game, despite any minor linguistic imperfections. I'll break down my assessment into four distinct categories  graphics, controls, sound, and replayability.

Graphics  The game's comic-like style is visually stunning, boasting sleek and detailed visuals with vibrant color schemes. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting a strain on your system, even on mid-range hardware. I've played the game on an Intel i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M graphics card, 8GB of RAM, and Windows 8.1, and it runs smoothly like clockwork.

Controls  The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, but it's also compatible with an Xbox controller, offering a more immersive gaming experience.

I've been playing for two hours, and I'm on the verge of dying from laughter. The gameplay is solid, the art design is breathtakingly beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and perfectly fitting, the story/world has me thoroughly enthralled, and the puzzles are delightfully engaging. However, the most remarkable aspect of this game is its comedy. If you've played any role-playing game since the dawn of video game RPGs, you'll be in stitches at the numerous jokes, parodies, and references; if you're new to the world of RPGs, you'll still find the game's humor endearing. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely must play this game, without giving away too many spoilers... I had to pause my gameplay after two hours to give my cheeks a break from grinning from ear to ear due to excessive smiling. What a sheer delight it has been so far.

I'm genuinely sorry, but I'm deeply disappointed that I couldn't find myself enjoying this game, despite my enthusiasm for free-to-play games and indie developers. The game's description initially resonated with me, but unfortunately, the execution fell short of my expectations. As a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I was excited to dive in, but unfortunately, I found the gameplay to be utterly unintuitive, and even after consulting online resources, I still struggled to find the experience enjoyable. The lack of a pause button is a glaring omission, particularly given that many sequences in the game are timed. This oversight seems inexcusable, especially considering the game's overall brevity. Moreover, I feel that the game is overly reliant on cutscenes, leaving me feeling like I'm simply twiddling my thumbs, waiting for something to happen.

This game was an utterly captivating experience from start to finish. The story was beautifully crafted, and I was completely absorbed in it. The narrative was not just a story, but an immersive experience that made me feel like I was the protagonist, trying to unravel the mystery that my character was unfolding. The gameplay was engaging, and I learned a lot about myself through this game, particularly about my fear of heights, which I never had a problem with until the ice caverns. My stomach was churning the whole time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you were to create a DLC or a sequel, I would be the first to buy it and wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone I know. A huge thank you to everyone involved in making this game, you created an absolutely breathtaking experience.

Sid Meier's Civilization  Beyond Earth is a turn-based game that challenges you to build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory' on a new planet. Unlike previous games in the Civilization series, this installment takes a bold approach by setting the game in the future, allowing players to colonize a new planet and navigate its unique challenges. One of the most innovative features of this game is the introduction of the affinity system and orbital layer, which adds a new layer of depth to the gameplay experience. However, some players may find the game overwhelming at times, particularly with the sheer amount of new mechanics introduced. To further enhance the game, it would be beneficial to incorporate more diverse and visually stunning artwork, such as the environment, to create a more immersive experience when interacting with other leaders. This could include the ability to explore and experience the environment in a more engaging and visually appealing way.

It's a shame I can't thoroughly recommend or enjoy this game, as from the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it didn't have the following two game-breakers. Unfortunately, the game is marred by two major issues  the lack of Aussie servers and poor performance. The lack of servers is particularly egregious, as one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage, causing unbearable lag. I've played through the offline training mode, and it was equally plagued by stuttering and lag (it's astonishing that this could happen). Combine this with the poor ping, and it utterly ruins the game. Furthermore, the game's artifacts, such as the menus, backgrounds, and in-game elements, are laughable. I've never experienced this level of poor performance with this graphics card and thought it might be an issue with my overclocked processor. However, I set my GPU back to stock settings, and, sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

I recently completed the game last night, and while it may not be a deeply complex or captivating story, the storytelling is what truly elevates it. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing it out. I gained a significant understanding of the Batman universe, which was a slight letdown, given the scarcity of boss battles. However, there is a bright future ahead, with upcoming games set to rectify this imbalance. The combat is well-balanced, with a suitable level of challenge, although it tilts slightly towards the easier side. Levelling up Batman wasn't particularly fulfilling, as it's the gadgets and upgrades you acquire during the campaign that add fresh gameplay mechanics. Unlocking previously inaccessible areas provides a sense of progression and accomplishment.

To venture to the moon is no mere pastime... Nay, it is a profound and unforgettable experience, and it was one of the most remarkable moments of my life. I must confess, I was utterly enthralled by Telltale's The Walking Dead, and it's no exaggeration to say that it was a highlight of my gaming journey. The narrative is a masterclass in storytelling, with a soundtrack that is nothing short of enchanting and pitch-perfect. Yes, the controls may be a tad finicky, and the gameplay may not be the strongest aspect, but the story is so captivating that I didn't even notice. Moreover, the humor is expertly woven throughout, adding a delightful layer of depth to the narrative without ever intruding upon its distinguished tone... And the references to the world of medicine are nothing short of brilliant.

I had initially acquired this game during its early development, when the primary form of currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree' in place. At that time, the game was still in its infancy, with all weapons being equally overpowered, which meant that there were no balance issues; any player could easily take down another at any given moment. Additionally, the game initially provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts, which might have been a generous offering, considering the sheer scale of the game's 'bajillions of guns'. It was only later, when I had amassed a collection of around three pages' worth of weapons, that I began to feel the need for more variety, as I was eager to explore new ideas and strategies. This was because, personally, I found the sheer scope of the game's arsenal to be a major part of the fun.

This game was a delightful discovery. The reviews of certain products often feature glowing praise, but in this instance, the reviews accurately capture the enjoyable essence of this charming game. It's an intriguing blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with panache. I found myself drawn to characters that I wouldn't typically appreciate in other MOBA games. Initially, I was skeptical about the potential for a melee tank, but I was pleasantly surprised by the outcome and ended up exploring more characters as they became available through continued gameplay. The art style and user interface are delightfully charming. As a result, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game, showcasing my fondness for this delightful experience.

I've recently embarked on a new gaming adventure, and I must confess that I'm utterly enthralled by this game. Hours can easily slip away as I become completely immersed in the experience, a phenomenon that hasn't occurred with a game in a while. The immersive atmosphere is largely due to the masterful combination of the soundtrack, sound effects, and controls, which all work in harmony to transport me to a world of endless excitement. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and the developers have skillfully optimized the combat mechanics to ensure an exhilarating experience. Initially, I harbored some reservations about the naval combat system, but it's surprisingly enjoyable to unleash havoc on multiple fleets simultaneously. The only way to succumb to defeat is to neglect the importance of strategic retreats and regrouping, and instead, I've found myself getting outflanked and defeated. Kudos to the developers for crafting an experience that has truly left an indelible mark on my gaming journey.

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought about a seismic shift in the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. The change may be jarring for fans of the original series, who have grown attached to the character. However, this new game by Ninja Theory proves that the alteration is for the better; and DMC serves as the ideal entry point for newcomers to jump into the series. The game masterfully crafts a compelling narrative arc for the new Dante, transforming him from an arrogant, cynical individual to a selfless hero. The story follows Dante as he is inducted into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore, presenting a gripping tale of his transformation from cynicism to selflessness.

This enchanting game is a masterpiece of storytelling, boasting an captivating narrative that effortlessly balances lighthearted humor with poignant seriousness. The game's attention to detail is remarkable, weaving together a tapestry of happiness, clever wordplay, and engaging characters with rich backstories and hidden secrets. The character designs are masterfully crafted, each with their own distinct personalities and motivations. One of the most refreshing aspects of this RPG is the innovative concept of not having to resort to violence, which sets it apart from other games in the genre. Drawing inspiration from the esteemed Earthbound, one of the most iconic RPGs of all time, it's clear that this game is destined for greatness. The soundtrack is a sonic masterpiece, boasting a score that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

I am recommending this solely because it's free, and it offers a potentially more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game failed to elicit a reaction from me. Half the story relies on shocking elements, but I wasn't shocked or emotionally moved in any way, which may be a result of desensitization or the simplicity of the narrative. The other half of the game attempts to paint a vivid picture of a person's mental decline, exploring themes such as obsession, hallucinations, depression, and other mental health struggles. In theory, the concept is intriguing, but the game took me 10 minutes to complete, which is a testament to the need for patience and attention to detail in order to fully absorb the information presented.

Does it even need to be said why Portal is an extraordinary achievement? Portal is a puzzle game that presents a concept, then promptly disappears, leaving you with an intellectual challenge that is both entertaining and mentally stimulating. Although this game may not be narrative-driven, it has given rise to one of the most beloved games of 2011, and I still find myself returning to it when I'm feeling under-stimulated, as I'm drawn to explore the origins of a phenomenon and the enduring legend surrounding it. Gameplay  Portal's gameplay is refreshingly straightforward, at its core. You utilize portals to your advantage, in combination with buttons that activate specific puzzle elements. There are two buttons in the game - one that you press, and one that requires a cube to be applied.

If I can overlook the minor bugs, which I personally experienced only two  one minor and the other quite frustrating, I can confidently recommend this game for space exploration enthusiasts. The recent edit has significantly improved my frame rate, increasing it from 60-90 to 80-120 frames per second. With its impressive specifications, including an i5-6600k processor, Radeon RX480 graphics card, 16GB DDR4 RAM, and a budget-friendly price tag of around 650€, this gaming rig is an excellent option for those seeking a high-performance gaming experience. Although some users may argue that this setup is overkill, I can attest that I've experienced a consistent 60+ frames per second on high settings with vsync enabled, which is significantly higher than the 20 frames per second reported by many users. Overall, I highly recommend this game for those seeking an immersive space exploration experience.

Remember the age of mythology? Indeed, it has been a long time since there has been an RTS game of such exceptional quality. Divinity  Dragon Commander comes close to my personal favorite RTS game. Combine this with a grand strategy mode that carries a high level of risk, and it hits the mark. I am not (read  I will not be) biased in my assessment, as this game allows you to transform into a dragon, providing support to your troops by offering guidance, leading units in attack and production, and even commanding unit deployment and spawning simultaneously. Honestly, I genuinely appreciate the complex RTS games currently available. I think of games like Civilization V and others. However, these games attempt to pack complex mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, intricate game mode.

The artistry of Undertale comes together to create a masterpiece that transcends the sum of its individual components. The retro aesthetic of the graphics and the melodic quality of the music harmonize to create truly breathtaking and emotionally resonant moments. The script masterfully navigates a range of emotions, effortlessly transitioning from comedic to dramatic to heart-wrenching to hopeful, often seamlessly blending multiple emotions into a single, impactful experience. Without delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay mechanics, I could write an exhaustive analysis of its intricacies. Instead, I'll simply say this  if you're a fan of role-playing games, do yourself a favor and play this game. If you're a gamer at heart, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your eventual demise, seize the opportunity to experience this remarkable adventure.

I've had the privilege of playing this game for only a few months, and in that relatively short period, two DLCs have already been released, accompanied by patches that have transformed an already impressive game into an outstanding one. The developers' commitment to the community is evident in the numerous discussion forums and developer diaries, where their dedication to the game's growth is palpable. While the game's mechanics may present a steep learning curve, the sheer breadth of strategic options available to me allows me to experiment with various approaches and capitalize on specific situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable, and I find myself becoming increasingly engrossed in each session, regardless of the play-through outcome.

Warframe is an entertaining game for the initial hours of play. However, after those few enjoyable hours, you'll begin to realize that the game's content is largely repetitive, with limited variety in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The one notable aspect is that the developers are actively working on updates, which typically include significant changes to the game's systems, new Warframes, and other features. While it's a great game for casual play, I'm skeptical it will maintain your interest beyond a few months unless you're deeply invested in grinding. Fortunately, the game's free nature makes it worth trying out. If you're seeking a quick distraction, give it a shot.

This game is a disappointing experience, to say the least. I was misled into thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a game I had fond memories of playing on the PlayStation 2. Unfortunately, it's a far cry from the original. The gameplay is marred by clunky controls and unoriginal level design, which makes for a surreal and unsettling experience. It's not just the gameplay that's the problem, but the game's atmosphere and themes, which left me feeling uneasy and questioning the meaning of existence. Every living creature in this game, from small pets to human beings, seems to be a mere prop, leading me to wonder if the game's creators had a fascination with taxidermy.

Here's my review of the game  "I was initially intrigued when I first learned about this game, as someone who is deeply interested in politics. The concept of a simulator for the road to becoming president seemed fascinating. Unfortunately, my excitement was short-lived, as the game's initial presentation was quite underwhelming. The game starts by asking you to choose a side  Republican, Democrat, or third-party options are not available. Despite my initial disappointment, I decided to continue playing to see what I could accomplish. I do give the game credit for its character customization, which, although limited, is still enjoyable to play around with. The ability to wear a head or not in a campaign is a unique feature, to say the least.

My gaming experience with this game was marked by a significant amount of time spent, with a total of 8.6 hours dedicated to reaching its conclusion. Throughout my journey, I discovered a total of 10 collectibles out of a possible 25, and unfortunately, I did not achieve any of the 15 available achievements. The aspects that I enjoyed the most were the visuals, which remained impressive until the very end, particularly the ice caves. While the story itself was not particularly remarkable, the ending, however, left a lasting impression, making the time I invested in playing this game feel worthwhile. On the other hand, the visuals in the final level were underwhelming, and the gameplay became increasingly frustrating as it became necessary to repeat the same tasks numerous times before achieving success. Moreover, the achievements were extremely challenging, with only 1.7% of players, including myself, managing to achieve more than 2 of the 15 available.

Pros  +Graphics. Cons 

- The game is marred by numerous bugs, particularly in the environment, which can cause frustration and even lead to becoming stuck or having your shots hit an invisible wall, despite having a clear line of sight on the enemy.
- The game's hand-holding and babysitting approach can be overly reliant on the AI, making it feel more like a chore to play.

Considering the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally underwhelming), I'm likely to put off playing this one until the very end.

It's not difficult for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. I have a vivid imagination and I'm more interested in playing immersive, room-sized games with controllers. While the game's scale is initially awe-inspiring, I also felt that same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were too steep for me. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be more engaging. However, I don't have the luxury of time, and there are many other VR games I'd rather spend my time on.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. The run-and-gun playstyle, which is often associated with this genre, need not apply. The recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon almost always results in death, unless it merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are essential if you wish to remain on target. It's crucial to be mindful of your ammunition supply, as there is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload halfway through your magazine, you'll be left with a pouch full of half-full mags. It's crucial to pace yourself, as sprinting for an extended period will inevitably lead to a decline in your aim. To maintain accuracy, it's essential to rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill, allowing your aim to stabilize. Your accuracy will suffer if you stand upright, as the adrenaline rush will impede your ability to focus and control your breathing.

"I must preface by stating that I did not purchase EU when it initially launched, and I acquired it on sale, which included EU and XCOM2. This allowed me to avoid the issues that some players have reported experiencing with the game. I thoroughly enjoyed EU, despite it being unforgiving in the early stages, as it provided a sense of accomplishment when I executed tasks correctly. In contrast, XCOM2 has been a different story. The game offers a rich RPG experience with a wide variety of ship types and physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles. The game features easy-to-learn resource management, allowing players to focus on strategy and gameplay. However, it's not without its drawbacks, including sub-par AI teammates, a limited selection of equipment types, and a linear leveling system with little branching. Despite these limitations, the game still offers a fun and engaging experience. The fast-paced action and constant sense of progression keep players invested, with the promise of new ships and skills to unlock and level up. To truly unlock the full potential of this game, mods are essential. The space combat is undoubtedly the main attraction, but the intense battles for resources are also a major draw. Overall, this game is a great starting point for fans of the genre, and with the right mods, it can become an even more enjoyable experience.

More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world are converging on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will engage in discussions on a range of pressing global issues, including China's economic prowess and Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. Notable attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among more than 20 government leaders and heads of state. In a departure from previous years, the WEF is expected to be less contentious, as anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, which will run concurrently with the WEF's more exclusive event in Davos.

As the clock ticks down to the midnight deadline on February 1, Fiat and General Motors (GM) are racing against time to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. The 2000 agreement, which granted Fiat the right to sell its car division to GM, is now at risk of expiring. GM, struggling to stem losses in its European operations, has reconsidered its interest in acquiring the unprofitable Fiat unit. The stalemate in talks has sent Fiat's shares plummeting 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% surge on Monday on hopes of a deal being reached. GM is reportedly offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement, citing Fiat's decision to divest its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising initiative as grounds for nullifying the original agreement. The 2000 deal was forged in a high-stakes game of musical chairs, with GM and DaimlerChrysler vying for a partnership with Fiat.

In a poignant Christmas message, the Cardinal Archbishop of Westminster, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, lamented the staggering cost of the Iraq war, suggesting that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better utilized to alleviate poverty, malnutrition, and disease. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day, the Cardinal reiterated his strong opposition to the war, describing it as a "terrible" waste of resources. He joined the Archbishop of Canterbury in speaking out against the conflict, which he believes has diverted funds that could have been used to make a meaningful impact in the lives of those struggling in poverty. The Cardinal urged 2005 to be a year of action, calling for a concerted effort to "make history by ending poverty and making a difference in the lives of those who need it most.

British stars suffered a crushing disappointment as they failed to secure major Oscars, despite being nominated in several categories. Mike Leigh's 'Vera Drake' missed out on the coveted director and screenplay awards, with Imelda Staunton failing to take home a prize for her performance. Kate Winslet lost out to Hilary Swank for Best Actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okenedo were overlooked for Best Supporting Actor. In a surprise upset, Andrea Arnold's gritty drama 'Wasp' took home the Short Film award, beating out fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar. The win was described by Arnold, a veteran of children's television shows 'Number 73' and 'Motormouth' in the 1980s, as 'totally overwhelming'. 'Wasp' tells the poignant story of a single mother struggling to make ends meet, outshining films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the iconic 1978 horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54, succumbing to a long battle with cancer. Hill, who co-wrote the seminal film with John Carpenter, is best known for her groundbreaking work on the groundbreaking horror classic that catapulted Jamie Lee Curtis to stardom as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopathic killer. Directed by Carpenter, the film's phenomenal success, grossing over $60 million worldwide, shattered the record for an independent film at the time, cementing its status as a horror icon. Hill's impressive body of work also includes collaborations with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her illustrious career as a production assistant, working her way up the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter to create some of the most enduring horror classics of the 1970s. The widespread availability of fast and reliable broadband internet access is fostering a culture of online self-expression, with more people embracing the freedom to express themselves online, as research suggests. According to a recent report by the UK think-tank, Demos, a quarter of broadband users in the UK regularly upload content and maintain their own personal websites. The study highlights the profound impact of having an always-on, high-speed internet connection is revolutionizing the way people use the internet. With over five million households in the UK now having access to broadband, this trend is growing rapidly. The report's findings indicate that more than half of those with broadband connections log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five admit to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the internet. Moreover, the study suggests that broadband is empowering individuals to take a more proactive role online, leading to a more engaged and participatory digital society.

Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is set to face a US court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival in the face of a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. The company is currently undergoing a process of being broken up by Russian authorities to settle the tax debt. Yukos had previously filed for bankruptcy in the US, with the intention of using international business law to prevent the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was ultimately sold for $9.4 billion to the state-owned oil firm Rosneft, following a state-led auction that was marred by controversy. Yukos' lawyers are now claiming that the auction violated US bankruptcy law, and the company and its main shareholders have vowed to take legal action against any entity that acquires its assets, using all legal means at their disposal.

The annual Bloggies, a prestigious award ceremony, is now open for voting, recognizing the most outstanding weblogs of the year. The nominations have been announced, and the website is bustling with excitement as voters flock to the official site to cast their ballots. This year, a staggering 30 categories are being honored, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. The blogosphere has had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named the word of the year in 2004 by a leading US dictionary. Technorati, a prominent blog search engine, tracks over six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 new ones are added daily, with a staggering one blog created every 5.8 seconds, according to research from the Pew Internet and American Life project. However, a concerning statistic reveals that less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months, highlighting the need for bloggers to stay active and engaged with their online communities.

China's Beijing-based Three Gorges Corporation, the builder of the massive Three Gorges Dam, is defying a government order to halt construction of one of its massive projects, the Xiluodu Dam, according to the Chinese State Press. The company is instead choosing to pay a fine for non-compliance, despite being ordered to suspend work on the dam, which is one of 30 large-scale construction projects halted due to a lack of proper environmental assessments. Additionally, the company has ignored orders to cease construction at two other projects, the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. As of now, only 22 of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order, while the remaining eight projects, including the Xiluodu Dam, continue to operate without proper environmental checks.

Manchester United's scrappy victory over Manchester City reduced Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points after a thrilling encounter. Wayne Rooney's cross to the near post, met by Gary Neville, was met with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne's volley over David James' head and into his own net added to United's woes. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from just three yards out in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United's approach play was more laboured than patient, and they managed to fashion just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar - in a first half that saw them struggle to create clear-cut opportunities. Their inability to maintain possession and create clear-cut chances left them unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race.

Newly appointed Health Minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, emphasizes the importance of learning from England's experiences in tackling waiting lists, acknowledging that Wales faces "big challenges" in the process. As he begins his tenure following the departure of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons expressed confidence in the foundation laid by his predecessor, citing the "essentials" already in place. However, Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats urge Dr. Gibbons to reform his policy approach. Sir Alex Ferguson has lavished praise on Manchester United's gutsy performance in their 1-0 win over Aston Villa, describing it as their most challenging away game of the season. 'That was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing,' he said. 'We showed a lot of character and guts, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do.' Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. 'Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which we needed, and which no other player has got.'

A highly anticipated documentary film featuring the life and career of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. The documentary, set to screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from February 10-20, offers a candid look at the highs and lows of Michael's life, from his early days in Wham! to his more recent experiences. The 93-minute film explores his journey from his early days as a member of Wham! to his later years as a solo artist, including his legal battles with Sony Records and his stance on the Iraq War and American politics. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16, alongside Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens. This is a unique opportunity to gain insight into the life and career of a music legend, and the Berlin Film Festival is honored to present this special event.

Billboard has made a groundbreaking move by incorporating digital music downloads into its main US singles chart for the first time. The hot 100 chart now combines data from sales of music downloads, previously only tracked in a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" currently ranks at number two on Billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. The incorporation of download sales into the UK singles chart is expected to occur later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's hot digital sales chart. Going forward, download sales will be combined with physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. The pop 100 chart also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales data, but it will only include airplay information from US radio stations that play chart music.

Scott Richter, the self-proclaimed "spam king" and founder of optinrealbig.com, is seeking bankruptcy protection as the company, which has been battling multiple legal battles, including a high-profile lawsuit against Microsoft, faces the possibility of being forced to cease operations. Optinrealbig was listed as the third largest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus and was sued in December 2003 for sending millions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The company's legal troubles began when it was accused of sending billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries. Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer brought the lawsuit, alleging that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages that violated anti-spam laws. The company's decision to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection would allow it to resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate.

Frank Arnesen, Tottenham Hotspur's sporting director, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There were newspaper speculations that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. However, Arnesen vehemently denied these claims, stating that there was only one reason for Santini's resignation  his personal problems. In a recent conversation with BBC Radio 5 Live, Arnesen revealed that he was unable to shed light on the issues that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. Arnesen expressed his respect for Santini, stating, "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland's impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield has propelled them towards their grand slam ambitions, with a resounding 8-0 lead at halftime. Scotland's early 8-0 deficit, courtesy of a try by Hugo Southwell, was quickly erased by scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell, which put the visitors in the driver's seat. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who contributed 13 points, further extended the lead. Jon Petrie's second try for Scotland was ultimately overshadowed by late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy, which sealed the win. After two hard-fought away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will strive to make it a memorable occasion for their coach Matt Williams by securing their first Six Nations victory, but they struggled to convert pressure into points when Italy comes to Edinburgh.

The Chancellor, Gordon Brown, has stated that the focus of the upcoming election campaign will centre on the economy's future, with Labour's poll strategy. This comes after a meeting at Number 10 Downing Street, where cabinet members gathered to discuss the election. Brown emphasized that voters will recognize that Labour has brought stability and growth, and will continue to do so in the future. Meanwhile, the Conservatives have outlined their plans to tackle the 'yob culture' issue, and the Liberal Democrats have provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. The Archbishop of Canterbury has written an open letter to all three parties, urging them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime. He called on them not to exploit people's fears in this election.

Irish sprinter Paul Brizzel will be one of eight hopefuls from Ireland competing in this weekend's European Indoor Championships in Sheffield. Alongside him, US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll will be the only Irish athletes representing their country in the event. Brizzel, who will be defending his 200m title, is expected to put in a strong performance in the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy is looking to confirm his place in the British team for the Europeans by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in top form on the European circuit in recent weeks, and his impressive performances have secured him a spot in the Madrid-bound team. Mark Carroll, who is currently ranked third in the world 3000m ranking, has confirmed that he will join Cragg in the European Championships. The duo's participation in the event is expected to be a highlight of the competition.

England's dual code rugby union captain, Jason Robinson, has set his sights on securing a dual code success against Australia on Saturday. The former rugby league international, who switched codes in 2000, will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 2 30 GMT. The 14 15 GMT kick-off marks a crucial match for England, who have the opportunity to secure their third consecutive international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as exacting revenge for their 51-15 thrashing by Australia in June. A win would be a massive achievement, especially for league. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over Canada and South Africa, and put an end to 34 years of disappointment against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Warning  Beware of a fraudulent website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The website may appear legitimate due to its outdated design, which mimics the official website of the disaster relief organization. However, it has no connection to the authentic site and has not alerted the authorities about its fraudulent activities. This is just the latest in a long list of scams that aim to capitalize on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The website's link is contained in a spam email with the subject line "Urgent  Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and the text is replete with grammatical errors and poor spelling, characteristic of many other phishing attempts. Do not fall prey to this scam. Report any suspicious emails to the authorities immediately.

Iraq is inviting bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has invited local, Arab, and international companies to submit their bids. The winning bidder will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The goal is to increase Iraq's very low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within the next 10 years, as well as develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. The details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on February 9th. Additionally, the ministry is planning a roadshow for investors in Amman, Jordan to provide further information and facilitate investment opportunities.

According to a two-year study, the number of women taking charge of protecting their home computers from malicious internet attacks is increasing, with a significant rise in the number of women purchasing programs to safeguard their PCs from virus, spam, and spyware attacks. The study, conducted by a net security firm, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of users. Notably, 40% of those purchasing home internet security software are retired individuals, a figure that has increased by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Interestingly, a higher percentage of retired women (53%) are buying security software compared to retired men. This shift reflects the evolving demographics of web users, as well as the growing awareness of the increased risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasting has revolutionized the way people consume audio content, allowing users to store up to 10,000 songs on their Apple iPods or other digital music players. However, this vast storage capacity has not been filled to its maximum potential. Many iPod owners are increasingly opting to fill this space with a diverse range of audio content, courtesy of an eclectic mix of creators. The concept of podcasting, championed by its most ardent advocate, former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry, has its roots in the term "podcasting," which was inspired by the Apple iPod. Notably, one does not require an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show, typically produced from the comfort of one's own home. To get started, all one needs is a microphone, a computer, and some editing software. Podcasters then upload their shows to the internet, making them accessible for free download and listening by others.

Andrea Levy's novel, 'Small Island', has won the Whitbread Novel of the Year award, marking a major achievement for the author. Levy's book, which was previously a favourite to win the overall prize, has beaten off the Booker Prize-winning author, Alan Hollinghurst, for his novel 'The Line of Beauty'. Meanwhile, Geraldine McCaughrean has taken home the children's fiction award for 'Not the End of the World' for the third time. The Whitbread Book of the Year award is a prestigious honour, with a £25,000 prize attached to it. A panel of judges, comprising Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will meet on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win, reflecting the strong public backing for her work.

Yukos, the Russian oil company, will seek court action in the United States on Wednesday to pursue sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that acquired its main asset. Yukos has announced it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to have Baikal assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for purchasing the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have reported that Baikal, which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-ordered auction, has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts FC wrapped up their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with a resounding 2-1 victory, scoring two goals in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring sheet with a stunning header, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free-kick in the opening 60 seconds. McAllister doubled the lead when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton's controversial goal arrived after an hour, but Hearts held on to claim the win. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken's clumsy foul on Miller 35 yards from goal, giving away a free-kick opportunity. McAllister's floated delivery found Miller, who outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. Scotland's Justice Minister, Jamie Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating that she intends to take action against them 'where it hurts most' by banning them from matches. This is part of a series of measures being considered to combat sectarianism in the Scottish Executive's campaign. Jamieson praised Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in tackling the issue, stating that stopping sectarian abuse linked to old firm matches is a key objective. The minister was speaking ahead of the third round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnel met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth, two Hollywood stars, attended the British premiere of the new film, "Beyond the Sea", at London's Leicester Square on Thursday. The film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin, marks Spacey's directorial debut. As an homage to the late singer, Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, singing all 18 songs on the soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays the role of Darin's wife, Sandra Dee, a real-life Hollywood actress. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds Tykes have made a significant boost to their squad for their Friday fixture at Headingley, as they welcome Newcastle's prop Ed Kalman and hooker Tom McGee on loan. Meanwhile, fly-half Craig McMullen joins the team from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez has been named as hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. The game at Headingley has been given the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. The team's 22-man squad is as follows  Balshaw, Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty, McMullen, Dickens, Rawlinson, Gerber, Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. The replacements are  Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMullan, Rock, Vickerman.

The study conducted by Nokia reveals that the traditional landline phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. The research indicates that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or receive. In fact, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, and South Korea now prefer to use their mobile phone for all their calls. The study highlights that people keep their fixed-line phone for longer calls, but most of those surveyed admitted that the future is definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research found that mobiles and fixed phones are used for different purposes. While home phones are used for longer calls, mobile phones are used for shorter conversations, primarily with friends. In the UK, 69% of those surveyed stated that they switched to their fixed phone because it is still cheaper to use than a mobile.

Shocking the tennis world, Jurgen Melzer delivered a resounding defeat to second-seeded Andre Agassi in the quarterfinals of the SAP Open. Agassi struggled to cope with the Austrian's cunning drop shots, ultimately succumbing to a 6-3, 6-1 loss in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick fought back to overcome Sweden's Thomas Enqvist, 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Unseeded Cyril Saulnier pulled off a major upset by defeating fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea, 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas outlasted eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi, 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. The cross-party group, which has tried to raise the pressure on Tony Blair over reform to the House of Lords, has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. The bill proposes a new upper chamber, which would reduce the power of the House of Lords, allowing for more democratic representation in the upper chamber. The group has stated that they believe they can win support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers, as well as changing the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto. Tony Blair has argued that there needs to be consensus on reforms, and that there will be proposals for changing the powers of the Lords in Labour's manifesto.

Scott Allan is confident that he can win a medal at the upcoming European Indoor Championships, following a strong debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos of Spain won the race, equaling the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 seconds, but ran 0.04 seconds slower than his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a specific date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs to be refilled, even when it does not. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's leading printer manufacturer, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP's ink cartridges employ a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. However, the suit claims that the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of whether they are empty or not.

Roxy Music will be headlining at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The three-day event will take place from June 10-12. The original band members, Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzerana, Andy McKay, and Paul Thompson, will perform on stage on the Saturday night of the festival. Roxy Music is also working on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Formed in 1971 by Bryan Ferry, Andy McKay, and Brian Eno, with Phil Manzerana joining the following year, Roxy Music gained popularity with their hits such as "Virginia Plain" in 1972, followed by "Street Life", "Love is the Drug", and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy".

Captains from six nations, including Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, will line up for the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also part of the Northern Hemisphere squad. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. "I am looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. This will be a chance for Woodward to assess some of his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he said.

Last night, the independent Spirit Awards honored the comedy 'Sideways' with a sweep of six awards, including Best Film. The film's director, Alexander Payne, and co-writer, Jim Taylor, took home the awards for Best Director and Best Screenplay, respectively. The film's stars, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen, also received acting awards for their outstanding performances. The Spirit Awards, now in their 20th year, celebrate independent films outside the traditional studio system, and are held the day before the Oscars. Other notable winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her powerful portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama 'Maria Full of Grace.' Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for 'Maria Full of Grace,' a gripping and poignant film that explores the complexities of human nature.

Prince, the 'Top Music Earner' of 2004, surpassed all other pop stars, including Madonna and Elton John, according to Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer's lucrative musicology tour and album sales earned him a staggering $56.5 million, a sum that far exceeded that of his closest competitor, Madonna, who earned $54.9 million from her global re-invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel, veterans of the music industry, took 10th place, with their comeback tour generating $24.9 million in revenue. According to Rolling Stone, Prince's return to the spotlight after a decade-long hiatus was a major comeback story. His 2004 tour was a resounding success, raking in a staggering $90.3 million in ticket sales, with his album, Musicology, selling a remarkable 1.9 million copies.

U2, the Irish rock band, have been honored at France's biggest music awards, but were edged out by the British boy band Blue to win the top prize. U2 received a special achievement award at the NRJ Music Awards, but Blue took the international group award. Maroon 5 was named the best new international artist, and took the best international song title for "This Love". Over five million radio listeners voted in the awards. The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively. Collecting his band's award from model Naomi Campbell at the Cannes ceremony, U2 frontman Bono said in French  'I'm not from this country, but I'll make a little confession to you - it's at the Côte d'Azur I feel at home.'

Walmart is launching a major public relations campaign to address criticism and set the record straight about its practices and corporate behavior. The retail giant has taken out over 100 full-page advertisements in national newspapers, including the Wall Street Journal, to push back against accusations and negative publicity. Walmart is seeking to dispel misconceptions and false narratives surrounding its employee compensation, benefits package, and promotional strategies. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly is also planning a campaign to combat "false" claims about its antidepressant Prozac. Walmart has taken the first step in this battle with a letter to the editor of the Wall Street Journal, penned by its president, Lee Scott, stating that it is time for the public to hear the "unvarnished truth." "There are a lot of 'urban legends' going around these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The proposals outlining policing plans for local communities would require residents to elect their own area police commissioners, under plans unveiled by the Conservative Party. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new role would replace "inefficient" police authorities. He clarified that the new office would not supersede the role of a Chief Constable. The Liberal Democrats, however, expressed concerns that the plan could lead to extreme groups dominating policing, while Labour criticized the "extravagant" Conservative promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the Chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, emphasized the importance of retaining operational independence. Jan Berry, the Chairman, warned  "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground.

At a glance, the UK's opposition has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants, should they win the general election. Here's a comprehensive guide to the plan  individuals coming to live and work in the UK from outside the EU. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with a high TB risk, they will be required to undergo a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who wish to stay a year or more will be subject to a full medical examination, covering tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result would automatically render visa applications being declined. All other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Doves soar to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, securing the number one spot, surpassing flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters. This marks a significant milestone for the trio, following the success of their single 'Black and White Town', which peaked at number six. Meanwhile, R&B sensation Nelly has taken the top spot with his new single 'Over and Over', a collaboration with Tim McGraw. The top ten is filled with a diverse range of artists, including Girls Aloud, Akon, Kaiser Chiefs, Futureheads, and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, '(Marie's the Name)', has debuted at number three, narrowly missing the top spot by one place. 'Wake Me Up' by Girls Aloud holds onto the number four position, while Akon's 'Locked Up' claims the number five spot. Hotly-tipped Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have secured their second chart hit with 'Oh My God', which has landed at number six.

Despite reported interest from the Ospreys, Mefin Davies is expected to remain with Gloucester Rugby, a development that would come as a relief to the club and its fans. According to BBC Wales, the 32-year-old hooker is keen to extend his stay at Kingsholm, where he has established himself as a key player. Having starred in Saturday's RBS Six Nations victory over England, Davies is likely to be offered a new contract by the Zurich Premiership side. The Welsh international's future was thrown into uncertainty following the demise of the Celtic Warriors region in the summer, which led to him taking a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained valuable experience with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, Davies has since spoken candidly about his frustration with the circumstances surrounding his departure from the region. His impressive performances for Gloucester have since earned him a prominent place in the team, and it is anticipated that he will be rewarded with a new deal in the coming months.

The Cabinet is expressing anger at the proposal to use Whitehall's cash to keep council tax bills down, with local government minister Nick Raynsford acknowledging the plans. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford stated that he had engaged in "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. He emphasized that local governments must deliver good services without significant council tax increases. The central government's cash is part of a £1bn package to assist local authorities in England in keeping next year's council tax rises below 5%, likely in the context of a general election. Mr. Raynsford noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in well-run local authorities.

A groundbreaking report from the University College London reveals that reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save significantly more lives than previously thought. The study, conducted by renowned transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, suggests that decreasing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would lead to a substantial reduction in fatalities. The findings are being published as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit.

Autonomous vehicle (AV) control has been shown to significantly reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central authority is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a novel joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal routing by minimizing tolls while ensuring user equilibrium and human-driven vehicles are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bilevel optimization problem, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and human-driven vehicles.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the creation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. This breakthrough has paved the way for the development of novel ideas for harnessing mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information, as well as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, including cat states or energy-squeezed states. Recognizing this limitation, researchers have proposed the possibility of circumventing it by creating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have indeed been achieved, but these have not yet accessed non-classical states of motion. Nonetheless, this research has opened up new avenues for the exploration of quantum mechanics and its potential applications.

Online reviews play a crucial role in helping customers make informed purchasing decisions.
